p: The virus has thus revealed the egregious socio-economic inequalities within and between countries (Zinn 2020). There is already abundant evidence that the coronavirus disproportionately affected the most socially marginalised groups—racial minorities (Yancy 2020), temporary migrant workers (Koh 2020), sex workers (Platt et al. 2020), prisoners or persons in custody (Kinner et al. 2020), homeless people (Tsai & Wilson 2020), and so on and so forth. Domestic violence against women has soared around the world since lockdowns began (Wenham et al. 2020). In developing countries, lockdowns would do more harm than good to the people in poverty, especially children (Broadbent et al. 2020).
